Award.AwardTitle: Building Cyber Security Capacity in Two Year and Four Year Colleges

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project at the Polytechnic University of New York (NYU-Poly) is training a cadre of two-year and four-year faculty in cyber security. The faculty, who are recruited from urban inner-cities with socially diverse, economically disadvantaged, and underrepresented students, engage in an intensive six-week summer cyber-security course and also participate in on-going, cutting-edge cyber-security research projects with their mentors from NYU-Poly. The program provides the faculty with arc of experience starting from knowledge acquisition in the summer workshop, application and integration of the knowledge in a research project, transmission of this knowledge as they teach their classes, mentoring of their student teams for the Capture the Flag challenge, and finally the culmination of their experience in the national Capture the Flag challenge conducted by NYU-Poly that attracts thousands of students. Faculty develop and hone their research, communication, and presentation skills, which are critical to their professional growth and success. The faculty are introduced to a topic of critical national need and mentored to develop and offer courses that, in turn, introduce their students to concepts and challenges in cyber security. The project team is disseminating the results of project through the competitions and the TeachEngineering digital library, for adoption by others.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of this project was to create awareness, proficiency, and innovation in the area of cybersecurity among the US two-year and four-year college community by:

  1. Training a cadre of two-year and four-year college faculty in the basic concepts of cybersecurity and engaging them in ongoing research projects at NYU-Poly.
  2. Helping two-year and four-year college faculty introduce cybersecurity concepts in their classroom and introducing their students to concepts and challenges in cybersecurity.
  3. Getting two-year and four-year college faculty and their students to participate in a nation-wide CSAW CTF (capture the flag) challenge conducted by NYU-Poly that attracts thousands of students and builds a community of participants passionate about cybersecurity.

As part of the project, 39 faculty went through the training in the summer out of which 18 were from underrepresented groups, The camp trained faculty in the basic concepts of Cybersecurity and engaged them in ongoing research projects at NYU Tandon. The project also provided them all course material in cybersecurity developed at NYU to take to their schools and use at their own universities.   It assisted them and their students to participate in a nation-wide capture the flag (CTF) challenge conducted by NYU Tandon.  Several of them wrote papers and grant proposals with NYU Tandon faculty and one of them, Prof. Qiaoyan Yu of University of New Hampshire, even got an NSF CAREER award based on the hardware-security research she started in the summer at NYU Tandon. Another received a joint EAGER grant with the PI based on the research she started last summer.
